[[File:Sheeba unveil her latest summer couture collection (14).jpg|thumb|Sheeba unveil her latest summer couture collection (14) Punjabi Salwar Suit]]
The '''Salwar''', is the traditional attire of the [[Punjab region]] and is known for its lively hues, rich fabrics and embroidery. The salwar forms part of the Punjabi suit which features three items - a kameez (top), salwar (bottom) and dupatta (scarf). The women's Punjabi salwar suit style has become popular all over the sub-continent and beyond<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2000/20000527/windows/main1.htm The Tribune Pran Nevile 27 May 2000]</ref><ref>Lois May Burger (1963) A Study of Change in Dress as Related to Social and Political Conditions in an Area of North India [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CGFBAAAAYAAJ&dq=mughal+kameez+kurta&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+punjabi+lokh]</ref> reaching even the remote parts of [[Ladakh]].<ref>Textiles, Costumes, and Ornaments of the Western Himalaya by Omacanda Hāṇḍā [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JFPnh9B5zncC&pg=PA278&lpg=PA278&dq=Textiles,+Costumes+and+Ornaments+of+the+Western+Himalyas+O+Handa&source=bl&ots=O8Y5jaDMu_&sig=wG-BjJ8_12ZPB0U2kHK2c5W8iSY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Kg13VN_hCrKd7ga3lYG4Cg&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBg#v=snippet&q=punjabi&f=false]</ref> It is also the national dress for [[Pakistan]],<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=OGd1VYycEMnuUNCQgZgO&id=PvoMAQAAIAAJ&dq=punjabi+salwar+kameez+is+national+dress+of+pakistan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=purely Basic facts about Pakistan, Issue 5 (1950)]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=l5Sb4e4cL7gC&pg=PA386&dq=pakistan+national+dress+punjabi+suit&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KryJVdqLDfSp7Aar_bqYBA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=pakistan%20national%20dress%20punjabi%20suit&f=false Nelson,Lise . Seager,Joni (2008) A Companion to Feminist Geography]</ref> since the later 1960s with the Punjabi salwar being used in government offices.<ref>Qadeer. Mohammad (2006) Pakistan - Social and Cultural Transformations in a Muslim Nation [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ll02P7G5XD8C&pg=PA69&dq=sindh+shalwar++baloch&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Nx2NVfS5OoWuUYeig5AH&ved=0CFkQ6AEwBg#v=snippet&q=punjabi%20shalwar&f=false]</ref>
The outfit has been a part of Punjabi tradition for centuries whether as the suthan<ref>[http://revenueharyana.gov.in/html/gazeteers/karnal%20Gazeetter%201892.pdf 1892 Punjab Gazeetter]</ref><ref>Kumar, Raj (2008) Encyclopaedia of Untouchables Ancient, Medieval and Modern [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e8o5HyC0-FUC&pg=PA51&dq=suthan+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6WGFVa_kOcm0UdvBgLAC&ved=0CB8Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=suthan%20punjab&f=false]</ref> kurta/kurti ensemble or the salwar jhaga (kameez)/kurta combination. The outfit includes the [[Patiala salwar]] and the [[Saraiki shalwar suits]] of the [[Punjab region]].
==Punjabi suit== The term Punjabi suit refers to the three piece ensemble comprising the head scarf, kameez and the salwar. However, the term also encompasses the older variety of the Punjabi suthan suit which is made up of the head scard, kurta/kurti and Punjabi suthan.<ref name="autogenerated5">Sidhu Brard, Gurnam Singh (2007) East of Indus: My Memories of Old Punjab [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UUdYFH9skIkC&pg=PA331&dq=punjab+sutthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=M4-aVaWkFceuU5zwmZAD&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=punjab%20sutthan&f=false]</ref>
===Punjabi suthan and kurta suit===
====Etymology==== The word suthan is derived from the [[Sanskrit]] word svasthana,<ref name="autogenerated2"/> which means tight fitting trousers which in turn is derived from the Central Asian word Samstamni.<ref name="autogenerated3">Archaeological Congress and Seminar Papers: Papers Presented at the 4th Annual Congress of the Indian Archaeological Society and the Seminars Held at Nagpur on the 10th, 11th, and 12th Nov. 1970, Volume 4, Part 1970 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=_xJuAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nwSFVfuFBseOU76WqIgL&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCTgK]</ref><ref>Subbarayappa, B. V. Indo-Soviet Seminar on Scientific and Technological Exchanges Between India and Soviet Central Asia in Medieval Period, Bombay, November 7–12, 1981: Proceedings [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IerQAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nwSFVfuFBseOU76WqIgL&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAjgK]</ref> The suthan are trousers cut straight and tight, as opposed to the salwar, which is baggy and can be full of folds.<ref>Edward O'Brien (of the Indian Civil Service ) (1881) Glossary of the Multani Language Compared with Punjábi and Sindhi [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=u10IAAAAQAAJ&q=multani+suthan&dq=multani+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gG-NVc3zNaHT7QbWq4CoBw&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA]</ref> The tight suthan is loose to the knees but the loose Punjabi suthan is loose to the lower legs and very tight at the ankles. The salwar ends in a band which is loose fitting. Despite this difference, people use the word suthan and salwar interchangeably to describe loose suthans and salwars,<ref>John, A (2009) Two dialects one region: A sociolinguistic approach to dialects as identity markers.</ref> with the loose suthan resembling the salwar.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yCRuAAAAMAAJ&q=sutthan+punjab&dq=sutthan+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=64uaVYOKNMf4UuDPjng&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBDgK Dhavalikar, Madhukar Keshav (2003) Archaeology of western India]</ref>
Prior to the use of the term pajama, the term suthan was used. Therefore, the woollen pajamas of Gilgit<ref>Knight, E.F. (1996) Where Three Empires Meet: A Narrative of Recent Travel in Kashmir, Western Tibet, Gilgit, and the Adjoining Countries [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3zl-b6g4GDIC&pg=PA277&dq=dardistan+++pyjamas&hl=en&sa=X&ei=a0uUVdTeFJajyASgrIaQAg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=dardistan%20%20%20pyjamas&f=false]</ref> are also referred to as suthan.<ref>Kapur, Manohar Lal (1992) Social and economic history of Jammu and Kashmir State, 1885-1925 A.D. [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3ecbAAAAIAAJ&q=gilgit+suthan&dq=gilgit+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jE6UVaXeM8ityASoj464CA&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA]</ref> However, these are not of the Punjabi variety. The churidar pajama was also referred to as the suthan.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ALpHAAAAYAAJ&q=churidar+pyjama+known+as+suthan&dq=churidar+pyjama+known+as+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=C0-UVa77A4P6yASey6vYCQ&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAQ Census of India, 1981: Himachal Pradesh. Series 7]</ref>
The word suthana was also used in [[Hindi]], to describe pajammas.<ref>The University (1982)Panjab University Research Bulletin: Arts, Volume 13, Issue 1 - Volume 14, Issue 1 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nvE7AQAAIAAJ&q=suthan+19th+century&dq=suthan+19th+century&hl=en&sa=X&ei=l_yEVY_FGIGoUrGIgZgN&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg]</ref>
<gallery> File:GuptaDanceMusic02.jpg|Ancient svasthana and varbana outfit worn during [[Gupta Empire]], the basis of the Punjabi suthan suit </gallery>
====History==== [[File:20th (Punjab) Regiment of Bengal Native Infantry. Painting by Walter Fane (1828-85), 1868.jpg|thumb|20th (Punjab) Regiment of Bengal Native Infantry. Painting by Walter Fane (1828-85), 1868]]
=====Suthan===== The use of the suthan in the [[Punjab region]]<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=i73QAAAAMAAJ&q=lahore+suthan&dq=lahore+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=svmTVYvWEYv8UIKGgKgD&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA W.H. Allen, 1925 The National Review, Volume 86]</ref> also called suthana in Punjabi is a survival of the ancient svasthana.<ref name="autogenerated3"/><ref>Catherine Ella Blanshard Asher, Thomas R. Metcalf (1994) Perceptions of South Asia's visual past [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HDluAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+punjab&dq=svasthana+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HgqFVeXjMMPcUbysgvAE&ved=0CEsQ6AEwCA]</ref> Svasthana referred to a lower garment which can be described as a type of trousers. The svasthana was in use amongst the rulers in the [[Mauryan]] times(322–185 BCE).<ref>Vishnu, Asha (1993) Material Life of Northern India: Based on an Archaeological Study, 3rd Century B.C. to 1st Century B. [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=zaJ5oyrqBakC&pg=PA11&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=svasthana%20trousers&f=false]</ref> Evidence of the use of svasthana amongst the ruling classes has also been observed in [[North India]] during the [[Kushan Empire]] between the 1st and 3rd centuries C.E.<ref>Archaeological Congress and Seminar Papers: Papers Presented at the 4th Annual Congress of the Indian Archaeological Society and the Seminars Held at Nagpur on the 10th, 11th, and 12th Nov. 1970, Volume 4, Part 1970 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=MraFVYSaF4KPU_i-gYAB&id=_xJuAAAAMAAJ&dq=kushana+svasthana&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+svasthana]</ref> It was noted in use during the [[Gupta Empire]] between 4th and 6th centuries C.E.<ref>Mohapatra, Ramesh Prasad (1992) Fashion Styles of Ancient India: A Study of Kalinga from Earliest Times to Sixteenth Century Ad [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=smSFVdO6F8jzUvW3gOgP&id=QO2BAAAAMAAJ&dq=svasthana+harsha&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=svasthana+]</ref> and during King Harsha's<ref name="autogenerated3">A. V. Narasimha Murthy, K. V. Ramesh (1987) Giridharaśrī: essays on Indology : Dr. G.S. Dikshit felicitation volume [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Q_-1AAAAIAAJ&q=svasthana+harsha&dq=svasthana+harsha&hl=en&sa=X&ei=smSFVdO6F8jzUvW3gOgP&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCQ]</ref> rule during the 7th century C.E.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QCfjAAAAMAAJ&q=Harshacharita++svasthana&dq=Harshacharita++svasthana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Pf-bVfGzM8PqUtCvgKgL&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAQ Journal of the Uttar Pradesh Historical Society Journal, Volume 23, Parts 1-2 (1950)]</ref>
A version of the svasthana has been noted in [[ancient India]] which sticks to the calves with narrow circumferences of the lower opening.<ref>Bahl, Vinay (2005) What Went Wrong with "history from Below": Reinstating Human Agency as Human Creativity [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9euGAAAAIAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBg]</ref> This is similar to the Punjabi ghuttana which is loose at the thighs and tightens at the knees and ends at the calves (with some versions ending at the knees and the lower legs being naked).<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WCBuAAAAMAAJ&q=punjab+half+trousers&dq=punjab+half+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2i-RVbbwJoupsgHxkbuADQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAg Proceedings - Punjab History Conference (2001)]</ref> This suggests that the use of the suthan is indigenous to the [[Punjab region]]. Ultimately, however, the svasthana could have been introduced to [[ancient India]] from [[Central Asia]],<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&id=bOxZAAAAIAAJ&dq=svasthana+trousers&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=svasthana+ Indian Institute of Advanced Study Transactions, Volume 17]</ref> but its use became popular amongst the general people in the local area during the medieval period,<ref>Thapliyal, Uma Prasad (1978) Foreign elements in ancient Indian society, 2nd century BC to 7th century AD.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9X4BAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+trousers&dq=svasthana+trousers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv2EVdnoNofrUqWKt9gH&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBw]</ref> particularly, the 7th century C.E.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> The wearing of the suthan and kurta continued to be prevalent during the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] period between 1526-1748 C.E.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=RpKVVYmMBevB7Abys7HwBg&id=T_mC-s_K-6sC&dq=punjabi+suthan+ghagra&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=punjab Misra, Rekha (1967) Women in Mughal India, 1526-1748 A.D]</ref> and has been in use in unbroken succession since ancient times.<ref>Aniruddha Ray, Kuzhippalli Skaria Mathew (2002) Studies in history of the Deccan: medieval and modern : Professor A.R. Kulkarni felicitation volume [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OT9uAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+punjab+unbroken&dq=svasthana+punjab+unbroken&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Yz6FVfLeB8W2UYG1gvgM&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA]</ref> The National Review (1925) notes that the suthan was in much use in the Punjab, generally in white washable cloth but on feast days of rich material such as Lahore silk.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=p_ubVdX_IoLkUaa6v5gL&id=i73QAAAAMAAJ&dq=suthan+lahore&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lahore W.H. (1925) The National Review, Volume 86]</ref> The svasthana was worn with the tunic called varbana<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=A1jrAAAAMAAJ&q=svasthana+tunic&dq=svasthana+tunic&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wWqFVeSIB4b0UpvsgqgB&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBg J. J. Bhabha (1969) Mārg̲, Volume 23 Marg Publications (1969)]</ref> which was tight fitting.
=====Kurta/Kurti===== [[File:Phulkari kurta.JPG|thumb|Phulkari kurta]] [[File:Women's Punjabi kurti.jpg|thumb|Women's Punjabi kurti]] [[File:Saraiki children wearing cloths & saraiki Fashion ofr children.JPG|thumb|left|Saraiki kurti]] The use of side slits in the straight cut Punjabi kurta can be traced to the 11th century C.E.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=irh9dvlLz3MC&pg=PA118&dq=kurtaka+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1laGVZziN8yBUfWDgOAD&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=kurtaka%20dress&f=false Ghurye, Govind Sadashiv (1966) Indian Costume]</ref> female kurtaka worn in parts of north India and was a short shirt, with sleeves extending from the shoulders, to the middle of the body, and had slashes on the left and the right sides.<ref>Yadava,Ganga Prasad (1982) Dhanapāla and His Times: A Socio-cultural Study Based Upon His Works [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=aY_I3zgxfpsC&pg=PA107&dq=kurtaka+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1laGVZziN8yBUfWDgOAD&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=kurtaka%20dress&f=false]</ref> This is the same as the modern straight cut kurta which has side slits and worn by women in Punjab.<ref>Sharma, Brij Narain (1966) Social life in Northern India, A.D. 600-1000</ref>
In modern usage, a short kurta is referred to as the kurti. However, traditionally, the kurti is a short cotton coat <ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7SdGAQAAIAAJ&q=kurti+is+punjabi+dress&dq=kurti+is+punjabi+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FRCHVY3YI4P-UM_GuvAD&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADgK Punjab District Gazetteers: Rawalpindi District (v. 28A) (1909)]</ref><ref>Compiled and published under the authority of the Punjab government, (1939)Punjab District and State Gazetteers: Part A].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6eY2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjab++kurti&dq=punjab++kurti&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6BWHVZL0Dou9UeetgOgP&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCQ]</ref>(without side slits) and is believed to have descended from the tunic of the Shunga period (2nd century B.C.).<ref>Panjab University Research Bulletin: Arts, Volume 13, Issue 1 - Volume 14, Issue (1982) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=PgKHVa7dK8arUazcgLgD&id=nvE7AQAAIAAJ&dq=kurtaka+punjabi+kurti&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sunga]</ref> The local style of kurti also includes the type that flares out around the waist.<ref name="autogenerated6">[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=b8JFAQAAIAAJ&q=punjabi+kurti++anga&dq=punjabi+kurti++anga&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAGoVChMIsvHjzrnnxgIV6xfbCh1M9gnd Punjab District Gazetteers: Sirmur state, 1934]</ref>
The traditional Punjabi kurti is front opening and is buttoned. Traditionally, a chain of gold or silver called zanjiri is woven into the buttons.<ref>Kehal, Harkesh Singh (2011) Alop ho riha Punjabi virsa bhag dooja. Lokgeet Parkashan. ISBN 978-93-5017-532-3</ref> The use of the kurti by women has been noted during the 1600s<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6-jZAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjab+kurti&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+kurti Dr Daljit Singh (2004) Punjab Socio-Economic Condition (1501-1700 A.D.)]</ref><ref>Sanjeev Prasad Srivastava, R. P. Srivastava (2001) Studies in Panjab Sculpture [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=W0SIptlc5rQC&pg=PA6&dq=punjab+dress+central+asian&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBjgKahUKEwiRlfnF9uvGAhUGPBQKHc8nA6E#v=onepage&q=punjab%20dress%20central%20asian&f=false]</ref> to the present day. The kurti can be front opening from below the neck to the waist, or cover the back but leave the stomach exposed with some styles fastening at the back. A variation of the kurti, known as a bandi, is sleeveless and is worn as a pullover with no side slits and front opening. A longer version of the bandi is known as a chemise which has a lace around its hem.<ref>Dr SIngh, Sadhu (2010) Punjabi boli di virasat. Chenta Prakashan. ISBN 817883618-1</ref> Both bandi and chemise traditionally have been worn by women indoors. Somer versions are worn as pullovers with no side slits and font opening. The [[choli]] is referred to as kurti in Punjabi which can be half or full sleeved and be hip<ref>Arabinda Biswas, India. Indian Costumes (1985) Ministry of Information and Broadcasting. Publications Division [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vdyBAAAAMAAJ&q=ghagra+kurti+-choli+punjabi&dq=ghagra+kurti+-choli+punjabi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBGoVChMI4_7xsenwxgIVCsAUCh1GhwCS]</ref> length. {{clear}}
====Design==== Punjabi women in [[west Punjab]]<ref name="himalmag.com">[http://www.himalmag.com/component/content/article/1961-The-Salwar-Revolution.html] The Salwar Revolution Article</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JihGAQAAIAAJ&q=ghagra+punjab&dq=ghagra+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nbtsVei0OqOf7gaFr4OgCw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAzgo Punjab District Gazetteers: Mianwali district (v. 30A) (1915)]</ref> and [[east Punjab]]<ref name="himalmag.com"/> (which includes [[Haryana]] and [[Himachal Pradesh]]) traditionally wore the Punjabi suthan suit which was made of a head scarf, upper garment and suthan.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=155wVdHvK4erU5WDgOgH&id=jGIBAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjabi+suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=suthan Sir Jadunath Sarkar (1958) Essays presented to Sir Jadunath Sarkar]</ref>
=====Types===== The Punjabi suthan is of two types: loose to above the ankles and tight at the ankles, or loose to the knees, and then cut straight and tight to the ankles.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=qR6LVbiwLJOp7AbF7YHYBw&id=NcRFAQAAIAAJ&dq=suthan+punjabi&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=shalwar Punjab District Gazetteers: pt. 1 Muzaffargarh district, 1929]</ref>
=====Loose Punjabi suthan===== It was noted by Alberuni in the 11th century C.E that the local drawers are of gigantic proportions.<ref>Kumar, Raj (2008) Encyclopaedia of Untouchables Ancient, Medieval and Modern [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e8o5HyC0-FUC&pg=PA239&dq=sindh+kurta+dress+medieval+times&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o9OKVYimMYjlUdWJhKgG&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=sindh%20kurta%20dress%20medieval%20times&f=false]</ref> This could point to the loose Punjabi suthan which, unlike the Punjabi salwar, has multiple pleats and is very baggy with many folds. The suthan can also be arranged in plaits.<ref>Wace, E.G. (1874) Report on the land revenue settlement of the Hazara District of the Punjab : 1868 - 1874 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=UPeUVeT9MMi9UbX_i4AJ&id=bMPTuskHAqUC&dq=hazara+kurta&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ending+above]</ref> Up to 20 yards of cloth can be used which hangs in innumerable folds.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=s-Y2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjab++suthan&dq=punjab++suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cYFnVarhJ8mS7AaE6oPYCQ&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ Punjab District Gazetteers (1932)]</ref> Some varieties, such as those of [[Chakwal]], can use between 30 and 40 yards of cloth which are made with overhanging pleats.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=eOtAAQAAMAAJ&q=sutthan+punjabi&dq=sutthan+punjabi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4eSaVY_JLsSP7Aa15byAAw&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCQ Punjab District Gazetteers 1907 Jhelum District ..]</ref>
The material used for the suthan is traditionally coloured cotton with silk lines going down and is called sussi.<ref>Punjab District Gazetteer: Reprint of Ludhiana District and Malerkotla State Gazetteer, 1904 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=E-c2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjabi+suthan&dq=punjabi+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=aXJsVfeSEsqM7Aa06IGQCA&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBzgK]</ref> Sussi was manufactured in various places such as [[Hoshiarpur]], [[Amritsar]], [[Multan]] and [[Jhang]].<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dXoiAAAAMAAJ&q=jhang+district+salwar&dq=jhang+district+salwar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Vf2LVcbUKsPqUrfngdAO&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg Gauba, Anand (1988) Amritsar, a study in urban history, 1840-1947]</ref>
Instead of the Punjabi salwar paunchay at the bottom of the salwar, which are loose,<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960">Mohinder Singh Randhawa. (1960) Punjab: Itihas, Kala, Sahit, te Sabiachar aad.Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab, Patiala.</ref> the Punjabi suthan is gathered mid way between the knees and the ankles to fit closely to the leg and end in a tight band at the ankles which is what distinguishes the two lower garments.<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/> The tight band of the suthan is a remnant of the ancient svasthana trousers which were tight fitting to the thighs. The use of loose material is a local development. The pleats of the suthan either gather in circles resembling bangles, or fall vertically to the ankles. As the distinction between the loose Punjabi suthan and the baggy salwar rests on the ankle band, some view the loose Punjabi suthan as another version of the salwar,<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6-jZAAAAMAAJ&q=punjabi+suthan&dq=punjabi+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=P96LVfe6AsGqUZGIgvgM&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ Singh, Daljit (2004) Punjab Socio-Economic Condition (1501-1700 A.D.)]</ref> with the definition of suthan being reserved for the tight Punjabi suthan. The loose suthan is primarily a female costume, but in some areas, such as [[Rawalpindi]], was worn by men too,<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Vu5BAQAAMAAJ&q=men+punjab+suthan&dq=men+punjab+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lBqPVePgI4uv7Ab66574DA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw Punjab District Gazetteers, Volume 28, Part 1 Rawalpindi. (1909)]</ref> which is also called tambi when worn by men.<ref>Bailey, Thomas Grahame (1919) An English-Panjabi Dictionary: Romanized [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=LOxpU2Kh7uEC&pg=PA126&dq=sutthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ppKaVZDRC4PuUM_XlNAK&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=sutthan&f=false]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Wf5tAAAAMAAJ&q=tambi+suthan&dq=tambi+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V-maVYW9A4Xd7Qa5gZ_oAg&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ Gazetteer of the Rawalpindi District, 1893-94]</ref> The loose suthan was also worn by men in [[Bannu]] ([[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]])<ref>[http://www.khyber.org/publications/031-035/sociallifebannu.shtml#Clothing Khyber.Org]</ref> which has historical and cultural connections with the rest of the [[Punjab region]].<ref>Social & Religious Life in Bannu Excerpts from Gazetteer of the Bannu District, 1887 (present day Khyber Pakhtunkwa, Pakistan formerly of British Punjab Province) [http://www.khyber.org/publications/031-035/sociallifebannu.shtml]</ref><ref>Pakistan Studies Centre, University of Sind, 2005 -Grassroots, Volume 33 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8_dtAAAAMAAJ&q=hazara+punjabi++n+w+f+p&dq=hazara+punjabi++n+w+f+p&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6h6VVfaiFcmVUZXqmbgE&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw]</ref> <gallery> File:Pahari women kashmir3.jpg|Women in Punjabi suthan 1890 File:Nihang Singh and Nihang Singhani.jpg|19th Century Punjabi suthan suit worn by the lady on the right File:Punjabi Sikh woman in Amritsar Punjabi suthan and short kurta 1874.jpg|Punjabi woman in Punjabi suthan and short kurta 1874 File:Market Place, Bikanir 1896. Woman on left in loose Punjabi suthan suit.jpg|Woman on right in loose Punjabi suthan suit File:Men in British Punjab army in tight and loose Punjabi suthans 1895.jpg|Men in British Punjab army in tight and loose Punjabi suthans 1895 File:A Punjabi woman in Kurti and suthan visiting the Attar, the pharmacist. 1852.jpg|A Punjabi woman in Kurti and suthan visiting the Attar, the pharmacist. 1852 </gallery>
=====Tight Punjabi suthan===== The tight Punjabi suthan is a variation of the ancient svasthana, and was still popular in the [[Punjab region]] in the 19th century. The tight suthan is baggy from the knees up<ref>Baden Henry Baden-Powell 1872) Hand-book of the Manufactures & Arts of the Punjab: With a Combined Glossary & Index of Vernacular Trades & Technical Terms ... Forming Vol. Ii to the "Hand-book of the Economic Products of the Punjab" Prepared Under the Orders of Government page 115 the tight suthan was also worn in Bannu which is now in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, formerly of British Punjab Province [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gg_JAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA116&dq=punjabi+clothing+in+bannu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=g7mTVdpMwfdSxqCZ-Ag&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=they%20fit%20tight&f=false]</ref> and tight from the knees down to the ankles<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1s5AAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=letters+from+india+and+kashmir&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ODODVeXaAYSTsAHpi5-4Bg&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=letters%20from%20india%20and%20kashmir&f=false Letters from India and Kashmir (1874)]</ref> (a remnant of the tight fit ancient svasthana). The tight suthan remained popular in the [[Punjab, India|East Punjab]] into the 1960s.<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/> In [[Multan]], the tight suthan remained popular till the early 21st century.<ref>Chaudhry, Nazir Ahmad (2002) Multan Glimpses: With an Account of Siege and Surrender [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=FCyOVe73Noy27gbFnongBg&id=_fxtAAAAMAAJ&dq=over+time+baloch+stopped+wearing+shalwar+of+their+ancestors&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ancestors]</ref> The Punjabi suthan is part of male and female attire and is part of traditional dress in the hills of [[Punjab, Pakistan]], including [[Bannu]]. It is still a traditional garment in [[Jammu Division|Jammu]] where it is held in high regard.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=hmSQVdiABaW17gapmr2QCg&id=gs27AAAAIAAJ&dq=tight+Dogri+pyjamas&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=tight+ Raina, A.D. (1968) Field study in Jammu and Kashmir]</ref> The Gaddi<ref name="autogenerated4"/> community wear the garment, especially in [[Pathankot]]<ref>Shashi, Shyam Singh (1977) The Gaddi Tribe of Himachal Pradesh: A Sociological Study [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XZk9AAAAMAAJ&q=gaddi++pathankot&dq=gaddi++pathankot&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cjyVVcz3N4HdUOvptZAE&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA]</ref> and Nurpur ([[Gurdaspur District]]).Its variation known as the churidar suthan is worn in the Punjab mountainous region<ref>GORE, Frederick St. John. (1895) Lights & Shades of Hill Life in the Afghan and Hindu Highlands of the Punjab. A contrast ... With maps and illustrations, etc [http://access.bl.uk/item/pdf/lsidyv39189ee9]</ref> especially by the Gujjar community in the foothills of [[Punjab, India]],<ref name="autogenerated4">Hāṇḍā, Omacanda (1998) Textiles, Costumes, and Ornaments of the Western Himalaya. [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JFPnh9B5zncC&dq=suthan+chamba&source=gbs_navlinks_s]</ref><ref>Sharma, V. P. Kohler-Rollefson, Ilse Pastoralism. Morton, John in India: A scoping study</ref> and [[Himachal Pradesh]]<ref>Kumar Suresh Singh, B. R. Sharma, Anthropological Survey of India, A. R. Sankhyan (1996) Himachal Pradesh [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XEduAAAAMAAJ&q=suthan+himachal+pradesh&dq=suthan+himachal+pradesh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_zSDVZuyMYqmsgHdmaPYAQ&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAQ]</ref> whereby the upper part is loose but below the knees, the tight part is sewn in folds to create a bangles look. When worn in [[Jammu Division|Jammu]], the suthan is referred to as Dogri pants<ref>[http://www.planyourwedding.co.in/hyderabad/fashion/the-rockstar-dhoti.aspx Banerjee, Sanhati. The Rockstar Dhoti (15.01.2012)]</ref> or Dogri suthan. This is the basis of the [[churidar]] pyjama, which in the [[Punjab region]] is also known as the (full length) ghuttana<ref>Abdul Halim Sharar, Rosie Llewellyn-Jones, Veena Talwar Oldenburg (2001) The Lucknow Omnibus [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=J6SVVe6lD4Gv7AaZtJmoAw&id=P1swAQAAIAAJ&dq=persian+churidar+pyjama&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sikhs]</ref> which was adopted in [[Lucknow]] during the 19th century. Where the churidar suthan is tight up to the knees and wide above, the churidar pajama is tight below the calves and slightly loose above.<ref>Hankin, Nigel B. (1994) Hanklyn-Janklin, or, A stranger's rumble-tumble guide to some words, customs and quiddities Indian and Indo-British [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rEZeAAAAIAAJ&q=persian+churidar+pyjama&dq=persian+churidar+pyjama&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J6SVVe6lD4Gv7AaZtJmoAw&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAzgK]</ref> The waist fits closer than the suthan.
Interestingly, in the late 19th century, the slim line riding breeches known as [[Jodhpurs|Jodhpuri]],<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2ZF5EIfX9VwC&pg=PA56&dq=jodhpur+breeches+origins&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OFqRVZTUFMHkUvGCsbgH&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=jodhpur%20breeches%20origins&f=false Singh, Jaisal (2007) Polo in India]</ref> were developed along the lines of the tight fitting Punjabi suthan, albeit the [[churidar]]<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vdyBAAAAMAAJ&q=jodhpurs+churidar&dq=jodhpurs+churidar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XpuRVbL-L4qy7QbyhaqYAQ&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBQ Biswas, Arabinda (1985) Indian Costumes]</ref> is cited as an inspiration.<ref>Albert, Jack (2011)It's a Wonderful Word: The Real Origins of Our Favourite Words [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CcsCBrxNXZQC&pg=PT72&dq=jodhpur+breeches+origins&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lY2RVd35PJCw7AaCyrPADw&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=jodhpur%20breeches%20origins&f=false]</ref>
Since the creation of [[India]] and [[Pakistan]], women of the [[Meo (ethnic group)|meo]] community of [[Rajasthan]] have adopted the salwar called khusni which, like the Punjabi suthan, is tight below the knees and loose above and is worn with a long kameez.<ref>Partap Chand Aggarwal (1971) Caste, religion, and power: an Indian case study [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xBguAAAAMAAJ&dq=khusni+meos&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=khusni+]</ref> <gallery> File:Cheetah and keeper Jeypore. Man in tight Punjabi suthan. 1896.jpg|Man in tight Punjabi suthan. 1896 File:Sepoys of 20th Punjab Infantry and Hunza Gun. 1893. Men in Punjabi tight from knees suthan.jpg|1893. Men in Punjabi tight from knees suthan File:Men of the British Punjab army in suthans 1895 Punjab Hills. Churidar suthan.jpg|Men of the British Punjab army in Punjabi churidar suthans 1895 Punjab Hills File:Punjab Hills 1895. Kulu woman in churidar suthan. Himachal Pradesh.jpg|Punjab Hills 1895. Kulu woman in Punjabi churidar suthan. Himachal Pradesh. File:Bharatpore maharajah.jpg|he Nawab Muhammad Bahawal Khan Abbasi V Bahadur (1883–1907) of Bahawalpur State in suthan File:Nawab of Bahawalpur.JPG|Nawab of Bahawalpur and generals in suthan </gallery>
=====Upper garments===== Punjabi women wore the suthan with a kurta, kurti, kameez<ref>Sir [[Jadunath Sarkar]], Hari Ram Gupta (1958) Sir Jadunath Sarkar Commemoration Volumes: Essays presented to Sir Jadunath Sarkar [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=DIaPVdunNqGU7Aag2IaACw&id=Sr85AQAAIAAJ&dq=punjabi+suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+suthan]</ref> or jhaga. The kurti could be straight cut ending at the waist or be a mini version of the anga,<ref name="autogenerated6"/> which ia a gown flowing to below the knees and even to the ankles (akin to the [[Anarkali Salwar Suit|anarkali]]) also known as an angarkha<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Vf4InPH0STQC&q=peshwaj+known+as+anga&dq=peshwaj+known+as+anga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I_xzVc64AoblUoiPgLAB&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA Rajaram Narayan Saletore (1974) Sex Life Under Indian Rulers]</ref><ref>Panjab University Research Bulletin: Arts, Volume 13, Issue 1 - Volume 14, Issue 1 (1982) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nvE7AQAAIAAJ&q=peshwaj+known+as+anga&dq=peshwaj+known+as+anga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I_xzVc64AoblUoiPgLAB&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg]</ref> and peshwaj<ref>B. N. Goswamy, Kalyan Krishna, Tarla P. Dundh (1993) Indian Costumes in the Collection of the Calico Museum of Textiles, Volume 5 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1IHWAAAAMAAJ&q=west+india+peshwaj+is+known+as+anga&dq=west+india+peshwaj+is+known+as+anga&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7AB0VfemDMKnU_u0gMgG&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ]</ref> which is similar to a loose coat and wadded with cotton.<ref>Punjab District Gazetteers - District Attock Year Published 1930 BK-000211-0160 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=CwV0VZfnNMnbU8OzguAC&id=3MNFAQAAIAAJ&dq=Punjab+District+Gazetteers+-+District+Attock+Year+anga&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+anga]</ref>
=====Variations===== Sometimes women replaced the suthan with a churidar pajamma, (a tradition noted by Baden-Powell in 1872 in his book Hand-book of the Manufactures and Arts of the Punjab)<ref>Baden-Powell, Baden. Henry (1872) Hand-book of the Manufactures and Arts of the Punjab [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HnAIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA105&dq=kurta+punjab+new&hl=en&sa=X&ei=m0VwVeLWLsv1ULWMgPgO&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=kurta%20punjab%20new&f=false]</ref> which would then be covered with a [[Punjabi Ghagra]] when going outdoors. The [[Punjabi ghagra]] has its origins in the candataka which continued as a popular female dress in the seventh century.<ref>Uma Prasad Thapliyal (1978) Foreign elements in ancient Indian society, 2nd century BC to 7th century AD [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9X4BAAAAMAAJ&q=candataka+dress&dq=candataka+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MGqGVbOqNoGyU_HYgfAM&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCQ]</ref> The use of the svasthana was also popular in this period. However, the candataka ended at the thighs and the svasthana may have been used to cover the lower legs thus giving rise to the tradition of wearing the ghagra and the suthan together.
Older Punjabi women wore churidar pajamma and long kurta. These different styles were popular during the 1960s in [[Punjab, India|East Punjab]].<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960">Mohinder Singh Randhawa. (1960) Punjab: Itihas, Kala, Sahit, te Sabiachar aad.Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab, Patiala.</ref>
Certain members of the Punjabi community however, were wearing the suthan and kurti on its own without the [[Punjabi Ghagra]], a tradition documented in the Gazetter of Hoshiarpur District 1883-84<ref>Gazetteer of the Hoshiarpur District: 1883-84. Sang-e-Meel Publications, 2001.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=kPuHVZKVNIHaUbXipJgO&id=eIpuAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjab+ghagra+suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+suthan]</ref> and also in the 1915 Hissar Gazeteer<ref name="revenueharyana.gov.in">http://revenueharyana.gov.in/html/gazeteers/hissar%201915.pdf</ref> Punjabi women (and men) also wore the ghutanna, a type of pajamma which was shorter than the full length pajamma, and was tight and ended at the calf.<ref name="books.google.co.uk">Paintings and lifestyles of Jammu Region: 17th to 19th Century A.D Raj Kumar [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=f-1XyQ2eIG8C&pg=PA145&lpg=PA145&dq=punjabi+suthan+kameez&source=bl&ots=8nBGZ6-YoE&sig=ogpJUiErn2LLs9ReDFnx_NXnW-I&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lbR0VM74KMWE7gbA3IDwBA&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=punjabi%20suthan%20kameez&f=false]</ref>
Although the use of the Suthan subsequently spread to the [[Jammu Division|Jammu]] area of the [[Punjab region]],<ref name="books.google.co.uk"/> [[Sindh]]<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=PGBxVeXsAsvkUpzTgsgF&id=ql87AAAAMAAJ&dq=sindhi+never+wore++suthan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=paro S. P. Chablānī Economic conditions in Sind, 1592 to 1843 (1951)]</ref> (where it was not traditionally worn) and [[Kashmir]], in the plains of the [[Punjab region]], the suthan was replaced with the Punjabi version of the salwar and the Punjabi kameez which gained more and more popularity during the 1960s.<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/>
====Punjabi suthan suit revival==== In recent years, the Punjabi suthan suit has been revived. However, the pleats fall in a variet of ways and the ankle band is not as tight as the traditional Punjabi suthan.
===Punjabi salwar suit=== [[File:Saraiki Tehreek.JPG|thumb|Saraiki region of Punjab, Pakistan]] ====Punjabi salwar==== In its strictest sense, the salwar is baggy and loose straight down the legs, and gathered loosely at the ankles. During the medieval period, people adopted the Iraqi style of salwar in [[Multan]] and neighbouring [[Sindh]].<ref name="autogenerated1">Kumar, Raj (2008) Encyclopaedia of Untouchables Ancient, Medieval and Modern [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e8o5HyC0-FUC&pg=PA239&dq=sindh+kurta+dress+medieval+times&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o9OKVYimMYjlUdWJhKgG&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=sindh%20kurta%20dress%20medieval%20times&f=false]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6xMNAAAAIAAJ&q=salwar+iraq+sindh+makran&dq=salwar+iraq+sindh+makran&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Th6OVe6fMdDY7AbjvoTgAQ&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ Said,Hakim Mohammad (1990) Road to Pakistan. 1. 712 - 1858]</ref> This type of salwar is traditionally very baggy and gathered at the ankles. It is still worn by the Kurdish community in [[Iraq]]. The presence of the baggy salwar was noted by Alberuni in the 11th century A.D.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> and continued to be envogue between the 16th and 18th centuries C.E. in [[Multan]]<ref>Dasti, Humaira Faiz (1998) Multan, a province of the Mughal Empire, 1525-1751 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=RLWLVf_yBMmjU7D4g5gH&id=kH3jAAAAMAAJ&dq=multan+shalwar&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+shalwar]</ref>
The Multani salwar is similar to the loose Punjabi suthan. Therefore, the distinction between the loose Punjabi suthan and the loose Multani salwar is fine and centres on the tight ankle band in the suthan, and on the suthan beginning to fit closer to the legs below the knees.
The original Punjabi loose salwar was not as baggy as the Multani style but was wide, with the gathering at the ankles being wide enough to cover the feet. Originally, up to ten yards of cloth was used to make Punjabi salwars.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UdP_sSKIxf0C&pg=PA243&dq=salwar+punjab++afghan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nsSLVaeaOMnvUtvpuOgF&ved=0CFgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=salwar%20punjab%20%20afghan&f=false Yarwood, Doreen (2011) Illustrated Encyclopedia of World Costume]</ref> The original Punjabi salwar was also not as baggy as other forms of the salwar, such as the type worn in [[Afghanistan]] ([[Khet partug|partug]])), the Balochi salwar,<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=NUyOVZPdHMGd7AbqkoPYDw&id=P8JFAQAAIAAJ&dq=bahawalpur+shalwar&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=discarded Punjab district gazetteers, Volume 7, Part 1 (1923)]</ref> or the loose Punjabi suthan, and gathers more quickly below the knees and ends in a tight band. Eventually the modern Punjabi salwar came into being which is slim fitting and does not have wide ends as before.
Another style of salwar is the Pothohari salwar of the [[Pothohar]] area of the [[Punjab region]].<ref name="Mohinder Singh Randhawa 1960"/> The Pothohari salwar retains the wideness of the Punjabi suthan. The kameez is also wide. The chunni is a remnant of the large [[Chador|chadar]] popular in [[Punjab, Pakistan|West Punjab]] known as salari<ref>Kehal, Harkesh Singh (2011) Alop ho riha Punjabi virsa Lokgeet Parkashan ISBN 978-93-5017-532-3</ref> and the large [[Phulkari]] worn in various areas of the [[Punjab region]]. However, the Pothohari salwar suit did not attain universal acceptance. The Bahawalpuri salwar is also wide and baggy<ref>Current Opinion, Volume 25 (1899) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=28RCAQAAMAAJ&dq=bahawalpur+wide+trouser&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=wide+trousers]</ref> with many folds. The material traditionally used for the Bahawalpuri shalwar and suthan is known as sufi which is a mixture of cotton warp mixed with silk weft and gold threads running down the material.<ref>Extracts from the District & States Gazetteers of the Punjab, Pakistan, Volume 2 (1976) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2RluAAAAMAAJ&dq=bahawalpur+suththan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=sufi]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wgEwAQAAIAAJ&q=bahawalpur+shalwar&dq=bahawalpur+shalwar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ok2OVbvYLsqy7Qai6rKoDQ&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAw The Pakistan gazetteer, Volume 5 (2000)]</ref> <gallery> File:Nawab Muhammad Of Bawalpur 1868-1900.JPG|Nawab Muhammad Of Bahawalpur (1868-1900) wearing a loose Bahawalpuri salwar File:Prince Suba Sadiq Abbasi.JPG|Prince Suba Sadiq Abbasi, Bahawalpur </gallery>
====Punjabi kameez==== The Punjabi kameez is also cut straight with side slits.<ref>Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association, Volume 138 (1961) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tusHAQAAIAAJ&q=punjabi+churidar+pajama&dq=punjabi+churidar+pajama&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qPF1VaCZMMfXUdbqg5AO&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBzgK]</ref> This combination makes up the Punjab salwar suit outfit,<ref name="himalmag.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA">Alop Ho Reha Punjabi Virsa Harkesh Singh Kehal</ref> which is very popular,<ref name="himalmag.com"/><ref>[http://www.hindu.com/mag/2004/10/24/stories/2004102400380300.htm The Hindu: article RAMACHANDRA GUHA]</ref> and was developed in the [[Punjab region]].<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=h9-BAAAAMAAJ&q=mens+punjabi+kurta+straight&dq=mens+punjabi+kurta+straight&hl=en&sa=X&ei=91t1VebDLoLXUZK_gagL&ved=0CDIQ6AEwADgU Bhushan, Jamila Brij (1958) The Costumes and Textiles of India]</ref> The [[Punjabi ghagra]] is now rarely worn.
Before the development of the Punjabi salwar suit, the traditional dress of women of [[Punjab]] was the [[Punjabi Ghagra]], Punjabi suthan<ref name="revenueharyana.gov.in"/> and choli/kurti/kameez.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>Glossary of the Tribes and Castes of the Punjab and North East Volume 1 Ibbeston, Maclagan</ref><ref>Publication, Issue 111 1965 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GyoGPpPN_E0C&q=suthanr+punjab&dq=suthanr+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBWoVChMIhpGMk-OyxwIVybIUCh3yPQ64]</ref><ref>Khan, Niaz Mohammad (1963) An economic survey of Abbaspur (Chak no. 2/10-L): a village in the Montgomery District[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GCPRAAAAMAAJ&q=suthanr+punjab&dq=suthanr+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBGoVChMIhpGMk-OyxwIVybIUCh3yPQ64]</ref>
=====Female dress: Punjabi salwar suit===== The [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] salwar Suit is worn in the Punjab in [[India]] and [[Pakistan]]. It consists of the chunni (head scarf), jhagga(kameez) and the salwar when worn by women. The chunni can be of varying lengths. The jhagga (kameez) is made up of two rectangular pieces sewn together with side slits, similar to a [[tunic]]. A kurta is also worn.
The salwar is similar to pajamas or pants, wide at the top and tightened loosely around the ankles with hard material, called paunchay. In the Punjab, the salwar kameez is also known as the chunni jhagga salwar suit. <gallery> File:MissPooja2.jpg|Punjabi suit File:Garba - graceful flow of colours.jpg|Girls in Punjabi suits File:Women of Puducherry.jpg|Women in Punjabi suits File:Rohi's Women Dress.JPG|Rohi (Cholistan) woman's bandhani dress (Punjab, Pakistan) File:Dance, Attari-Wagah, Punjab (10691014775).jpg|Dance, Attari-Wagah, women wearing Punjabi suits </gallery>
=====Male Dress: Punjabi salwar suit===== In some parts of the [[Punjab region]], especially the urban areas of [[Punjab, Pakistan]],<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GQTABKAGaVgC&pg=PA119&dq=kurta+new+style+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WkxwVfbTD4bSU4Dag5AG&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=chaadar&f=false Malik, Iftikhar Haider (2006) Culture and Customs of Pakistan]</ref> males wear the men's Punjabi suit. The upper garment is made of the straight cut kurta/kameez and the salwar resembles a slim fit pajama. In the past, the suthan was also commonly worn by men,<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OeU2AQAAMAAJ&q=punjabi++suthan&dq=punjabi++suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBjgUahUKEwjy8_zEnpHGAhVL7xQKHWUlAPo Punjab District and State Gazetteers: Part A (1911)]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=R6EIAAAAQAAJ&q=suthan+punjabi&dq=suthan+punjabi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6yCLVaukCKqU7QbXgbG4Ag&ved=0CDAQ6AEwBDge Land revenue settlement reports 1876]</ref> a trend which can still be seen in some parts of the region (especially [[Jammu]] and [[Himachal Pradesh]]). <gallery> File:Shalvaar qamiz.JPG|Men's Punjabi salwar suit File:Punjabi kurta Ferozepur 1845.jpg|Punjabi kurta Ferozepur 1845 </gallery>
===Early History===
====Salwar==== Salwar is the generic term used to describe the lower garment developed in different regions. The earliest form of the salwar originated in [[Central Asia]] amongst the [[Turkic peoples|Turks]] and its use was spread to [[Afghanistan]], [[India]], [[Iran]], the [[Arab]] world, [[Turkey]] and wherever the [[Turkic peoples|Turks]] established their empires.<ref>Jirousek, Charlotte. “Islamic Clothing.” In Encyclopedia of Islam. New York: Macmillan Pub. 2005.</ref> The [[Ottomans]] spread the use of the salwar throughout its empire.<ref>Annette Lynch, Mitchell D. Strauss (2014) Ethnic Dress in the United States: A Cultural Encyclopedia [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tiEvBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA142&dq=chalvar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBTgeahUKEwjDubCPyOzGAhXIsxQKHR20Dt4#v=onepage&q=chalvar&f=false]</ref>
The use of the salwar in the [[Punjab region]] has been the result of influences from the Middle East, Central Asian Turks<ref>Martin, Richard C. (2004) Encyclopedia of Islam and the Muslim World: A-L, Volume 1 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OVcUAQAAIAAJ&q=sirwal+central+asia&dq=sirwal+central+asia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QCCgVeuuCsTB7ga635_gBg&ved=0CB8Q6AEwADgK]</ref> and finally, the Afghans.
In India, the term salwar includes the [[Sindhi dress|Sindhi suthan]], [[Punjab]]i suthan,<ref>Dr Singh, Daljit (2004) Punjab Socio-Economic Condition (1501-1700 A.D.) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6-jZAAAAMAAJ&q=punjab+kurta+suthan&dq=punjab+kurta+suthan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pn1nVaGAGLOM7AaB8YOQBQ&ved=0CF4Q6AEwCA]</ref> [[Jammu dress|Dogri pajamma]] and the [[churidar]]. The term salwar kameez also includes the Kashmiri [[Phiran|Phiran/suthan outfit]].
In the [[Punjab region]], the salwar was made using a large amount of material but had no pleats or folds. The large salwar eventually gave rise to the Punjabi salwar.<ref name="autogenerated2">Paintings and Lifestyles of Jammu Region: From 17th to 19th Century A.D Raj Kumar [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=f-1XyQ2eIG8C&pg=PA352&lpg=PA352&dq=Paintings+and+Lifestyles+of+Jammu+Region:+From+17th+to+19th+Century+A.D.&source=bl&ots=8nBHQb20ox&sig=hehEhqbYaQ_NVTmqKdoksvPYpcY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xQt3VPu1Ms6V7AbByYHwBQ&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=punjab&f=false]</ref>
====Jhagga (kameez)==== In Turkic Central Asian culture, the salwar is accompanied by a tunic, forming the upper garment.<ref>Aryan, K.C (1983) The Cultural Heritage of Punjab, 3000 B.C. to 1947 A.D. [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hCtuAAAAMAAJ&q=multan++salwar&dq=multan++salwar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBjgKahUKEwiI-7Ss1pHGAhVJsxQKHbL5AE8]</ref> In the [[Punjab region]], the upper garment is the jhagga (kameez). The [[Ghaznavid]] Turks popularised the salwar/tunic attire in Afghanistan and Northern India,<ref>Jirousek, Charlotte. “Islamic Clothing.” In Encyclopedia of Islam. New York: Macmillan Pub. (2004)[http://char.txa.cornell.edu/islamicclothes.htm]</ref><ref>Flood, Finbarr Barry (2009) Objects of Translation: Material Culture and Medieval "Hindu-Muslim" Encounter [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OLNE_li8C10C&pg=PA64&dq=kurta+sind+iraq&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qwCLVZ7COeHd7gawvoNo&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBg#v=snippet&q=trousers&f=false]</ref> especially in the [[Punjab region]].
==Other areas== The use of the suthan or the salwar has been adopted in other areas. People in [[Jammu]] have changed the traditional attire from the peshwaj (flowing to the ankles) <ref>Textiles, Costumes and Ornaments of the Western Himalyas O Handa</ref> to the kurta and Dogri suthan. In addition to the traditional lengha choli, women in [[Sindh]] wear the cholo (kameez) and suthan.<ref>I am a Sindhi: The Glorious Sindhi Heritage and Culture and Folklore of Sindh J P Vaswami</ref><ref>Sindh and The Races That Inhabit the Valley of the Indus Richard F Burton</ref> The Punjabi salwar suit is also worn by many people. The [[Phiran]] in [[Kashmir]]<ref>Paintings and lifestyles of Jammu Region: 17th to 19th Century A.D Raj Kumar</ref> traditionally flowed to the ankles, is now of varying lengths and is worn with a loose suthan. [[Kashyap Bandhu]] is regarded as the person responsible for spreading the use of the suthan with the phiran amongst the communities that resisted to adopt its use, eventually leading to the use of the salwar.<ref>Cultural Heritage of India- Kashmiri Pandit Contribution. The Publication of Kashmir Sabha, Calcutta (1999-2000) [http://koausa.org/vitasta/pdf/Vitasta1999-2000.pdf]</ref> However, the traditional Kashmiri suthan is loose, similar to the styles worn in [[Afghanistan]]<ref>Asoke Kumar Bhattacharyya, Pradip Kumar Sengupta Foundations of Indian Musicology: Perspectives in the Philosophy of Art and Culture (1991) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8EJw6O4VFFsC&pg=PA110&dq=ghagra+in+himachal+pradesh&hl=en&sa=X&ei=igRuVbfNO-n5ywPdsoOoCg&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=pheran&f=false]</ref> with some wearing styles similar to the Dogri suthan. The Punjabi salwar suit has also become popular.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=x510VZv8Ece0UfCIgeAL&id=PwM7AAAAMAAJ&dq=shalwar+kameez+kashmir&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=shalwar+kameez Dhar, Somnath (1986) Jammu and Kashmir folklore]</ref>
Elsewhere in [[India]] and [[Pakistan]], Muslim communities have traditionally worn the style of salwar worn by the [[Mughals]] combining them with [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] upper garments such as the jamma. However, the Punjabi salwar suit is now worn by members of various communities in India<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=iY4bVR9--XAC&pg=PA141&dq=punjab+kurta+history&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gph0VfTWNMPpUovugOgJ&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=punjab%20kurta%20history&f=false Subba, J.R (2008) History, Culture and Customs of Sikkim]</ref> and Pakistan.
The traditional male dress in Bangladesh is the lungi and kurta (also called Panjabi). Men also wear the Pathani suit. The traditional female dress is the sari but women also wear the Punjabi salwar suit.
The salwar is a traditional garment in [[Afghanistan]] worn by men as the [[Khet partug]] outfit. The Khet is the tunic, similar to a robe and the partoog is the Afghanistan salwar, with multiple pleats. The male dress also includes the [[perahan tunban]]. The Pathani suit <ref>{{cite web|title=Celebrating Indianness|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/fashion/designers/Celebrating-Indianness/articleshow/7792864.cms?referral=PM|work=.indiatimes.com|accessdate=27 March 2014|date=Mar 27, 2011}}</ref> has become popular since the 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Perahan Tunban 'Mens clothes'|url=http://www.afghanistan-culture.com/perahan-tunban.html|work=afghanistan-culture.com|accessdate=27 March 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bY8ck6iktikC&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=afghan+sikh+culture&source=bl&ots=HZnJ_-ozKa&sig=5bNpi6TwiBI0HurXXg6IZs6xc8Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=LnBqVNCeBsPLaK_XgOAB&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=afghan%20sikh%20culture&f=false Culture and Customs of Afghanistan By Hafizullah Emadi ]</ref> The female Punjabi suit is also popular in [[Afghanistan]] which is called the Panjabi.<ref>[http://missbspage.weebly.com/uploads/1/3/9/8/13980362/afghanistan_clothing.pdf Afghanistan clothing]</ref><ref>Pia Karlsson, Amir Mansory (2007) An Afghan dilemma: education, gender and globalisation in an Islamic context [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=RGElAQAAIAAJ&dq=afghan+and+punjabi+dress&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+punjabi+]</ref>

{{About|the clothing|the song by [[Childish Gambino]]|Sweatpants (song)}} {{refimprove|date=April 2013}} [[Image:sweatpants.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Three boys wearing [[grey]] sweatpants.]]
'''Sweatpants''' are a [[casual]] variety of soft [[trousers]] intended for [[comfort]] or [[sportswear (activewear)|athletic]] purposes, although they are now worn in many different situations. In Britain, Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa they are known as '''[[tracksuit]] bottoms''' or '''jogging bottoms'''. In Australia, they are also commonly known as ''' trackpants''', '''trackies''' or '''tracky daks'''.<ref>{{cite news|title=In her tracky daks, a Hollywood star turns invisible|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/10/24/1035416934724.html|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=25 October 2002|author=Lisa Pryor|language=|quote=Naomi Watts: 'I look like a completely different person when I just wake up and get my tracky daks on'}}</ref>
==History== The first pair of sweatpants was introduced in the 1920s by [[Émile Camuset]]. He was the founder of [[Le Coq Sportif]]. The sweatpants were simple knitted gray jersey pants that allowed athletes to stretch and run comfortably.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asicentral.com/news/magazines/wearables/novdec-2014/sweatpants-the-comfortable-choice/ |title= Sweatpants History: The Comfortable Choice |publisher=ASI|date=29 May 2007 |accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref>
== Design == Sweatpants are usually made from [[cotton]] or [[polyester]], often of a heavy knit. They often have elastic in the waist, and may or may not have pockets. Sweatpants are traditionally [[ash gray]] in color but are now available in most colors. They are usually quite "baggy" and loose, making them easy to put on and take off; moreover they have flexibility and comfort. In addition, this design traps less heat than most conventional, lightweight trousers, which may be a disadvantage in some conditions such as cold [[temperature]]s and an advantage in others such as [[Thermoregulation|body heat]]-increasing [[aerobic exercise|aerobic]] activities. Warmer varieties can be made from [[polar fleece]].
Once these practical pants were only worn for sporting events and at home. Now, they are available in many fashionable styles and are worn in a variety of public situations. Because of their comfort and fashion, they have become a popular choice of clothing. The sweatpant variations described below are made from many different materials and in many forms.
== Variations == [[File:Woman fitness training.JPEG|thumb|Woman wearing tearaway pants]] There are many variations on the sweatpant design that have evolved to define their own categories of athletic pants. These variations include '''fashion pants''', '''windpants''', '''tearaway pants''', and '''muscle pants'''.
=== Fashion pants === '''Fashion pants''' typically refers to "[[fashion]] conscious" [[sportswear (activewear)|sportswear]]. These pants are often made from a variety of materials, like [[velvet]] or [[satin]], and in many color combinations or patterns. One distinguishing characteristic is that fashion pants generally lack the elastic band at the ankles.
=== Windpants === Windpants are similar to sweatpants but are lighter and shield the wearer from cold [[wind]] rather than insulate. Windpants are typically made of polyester or [[nylon]], with a liner made of cotton or polyester. The nylon material's natural friction against both itself and human legs makes "swooshing" sounds during walking. Windpants often have zippers on each ankle, letting athletes unzip the end of each leg allowing the pants to be pulled over their footwear.
==={{visible anchor|Tearaway pants}}=== '''Tearaway pants''', also known as ''breakaway pants'', ''rip-off pants'', or (in the UK) ''popper pants'', are closely related to windpants. Tearaway pants are windpants with [[snap fastener]]s running the length of both legs. The snaps allow athletes to remove their tearaway pants in a timely manner to compete in some sports. [[Basketball]] and [[track and field]] are the two sports most commonly associated with tearaway pants.

{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=March 2015}}{{underlinked|date=March 2015}}{{sections|date=March 2015}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2015}} }} '''Rang Panchami''' is a [[festival]] celebrated 5 days after [[Holi]].
Holy_krishna: It is celebrated on the fifth day (Panchami) in the dark fortnight of the Hindu lunar month of Phalgun by throwing a red, fragrant powder (gulal) and splashing coloured water, etc. on others.
The fire, which shines with its brilliance on Holi, decomposes the raja-tama particles in the atmosphere and this helps activate various Deities in the form of colours. This bliss is celebrated by throwing colours in the air. Thus, Rang Panchami is a symbol of victory over raja-tama. Rang Panchami, played on Falgun Vadya Panchami involves invocation of Gods and is a part of worship of the manifest form of Gods. Its purpose is to activate the five elements of radiant manifest colours and to touch and feel the Deities who are attracted to the respective colours. These five elements are a source, which help activate the element of the Deities according to the spiritual emotion of the [[Jiva]]. Rang Panchami is the worship of the saviour form of the Deities.
Rang panchmi (“color fifth”) occurs on the fifth lunar day of the month of chet. Holi occurs on the first day of that month and is celebrated in villages (see “rural Madhya Pradesh, holi”). In small towns the main celebration occurs on panchmi. In the event documented here, a procession headed by a water tank with high pressure jet, two ceremonial cannons (firing paper), and a camel – organized by Brijesh Bohra – circumambulated the town dousing everyone on the street, and anyone visible in neighboring houses, with colored water. Bhang and alcohol intensify the heightened sensations of this exuberant communitas.
People of [[Maharashtra]] commonly know this festival of colours by the name of Rangpanchami as the play of colours is reserved for the fifth day here. Locals of Maharashtra also know Holi as Shimga or Shimgo. The festival is particularly popular amongst fisher folk. They celebrate it in on a large scale and revel in the festivities by singing, dancing and merry-making. This special dance provide them means to release all their repressed feelings, needs and desires. People also utter sound through their mouths in a peculiar fashion by striking their mouths with the back of their hands.
Ranga Panchami, or Rangpanchami, is colorfully celebrated on the fifth day after full moon in the month of Phalguna or Falgun. In 2015, the date of Rang Panchami is March 11. People play with colors on Rang Panchami day and it is observed five days after the popular Holi festival. Rangpanchami is more popular in Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh and in some parts of North India. Rang means color and Panchami means the fifth day during a lunar fortnight. The festival of Rangpanchami is also associated with Holi festival but is not very popular as it is more of a traditional festival and is limited to Maharashtra. Some people confuse Rang Panchami with the Holi festival that is celebrated with colors the day after the lighting of fires on the Phalgun Purnima day. The Rangpanchami festival is more closely associated with rural Marathi culture.
The 2016 date is March 28.<ref>http://www.drikpanchang.com/festivals/month/festivals-march.html?year=2016</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Hindu festivals]] [[Category:Holi]] [[Category:March observances]] [[Category:Religious festivals in India]]

{{Main|College admissions in the United States}}
A '''college interview''' is a short<ref>Note: it usually lasts 20 minutes to an hour</ref> face-to-face meeting, usually between a college admissions officer and a high school student applying for admission. It is one of several ways for a college to assess an applicant along with grade transcripts and standardized scores and essays.<ref name=twsMay2S213>{{cite news |author= Howard and Matthew Greene |title= PBS: 'Ten Steps to College' (transcript) |newspaper= Washington Post |date= October 22, 2003 |url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A21178-2003Oct13.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> Interviews can take place on the college campus, at the high school (if the college sends representatives), and elsewhere such as at a local coffee shop if there is an interview between a student and an alumnus. In addition, several colleges have been experimenting with online interviews.<ref name="twsWashPost5">{{cite web | author= Barbara Rodriguez of the Associated Press | date= January 2, 2009 | publisher= Washington Post | url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/01/AR2009010101935.html | title= More Colleges Expected to Offer Online Interviews | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=... Avery Cullinan put on her best outfit but didn't bother with shoes. She sat in her living room, smiled into her computer's webcam and told an admissions officer more than 800 miles away that Wake Forest University was right for her...}}</ref> If offered by a college, interviews are sometimes described as optional, but one report suggested that not doing an interview when one was offered could hinder chances for admission.<ref name=twsL24>{{cite news |author= Steve Cohen |title= Top 10 myths of college admissions |publisher= ''The Washington Post'' |date= September 23, 2011 |url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/post/top-10-myths-of-college-admissions/2011/09/22/gIQAEn8XoK_blog.html |accessdate= 2011-12-12 }}</ref> Further, doing an interview signals an interest in attending.<ref name=twsMay2R214>{{cite news |author= Valerie Strauss |title= A new college admissions bible |newspaper= Washington Post |date= 2011-10-03 |url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/post/a-new-college-admissions-bible/2011/10/02/gIQAZVhqHL_blog.html |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref>
[[File:Tips for how to prepare for a college interview.png|thumb|right|300px|]] Likely interview questions include: #Can you tell me a little about yourself?<ref name="twsUSAToday1"/> #Why are you interested in our college?<ref name="twsUSAToday1"/> #What are you interested in studying?<ref name="twsUSAToday1"/> #How will you contribute to our campus community?<ref name="twsUSAToday1"/> #What do you see yourself doing ten years from now?<ref name="twsUSAToday1">{{cite web | author= Erica Cirino of Varsity Tutors | date= November 7, 2015 | publisher= USA Today | url= http://college.usatoday.com/2015/11/07/5-college-interview-questions-you-should-know-how-to-answer/ | title= 5 college interview questions you should know how to answer | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...1. CAN YOU TELL ME A LITTLE ABOUT YOURSELF?... }}</ref>
[[File:Tips for how to handle a college interview.png|thumb|right|300px|]] Counselors and teachers and professional consultants offer differing guidelines about interviews. Most suggest that an interviewee should "dress to impress",<ref name="twsUSAToday2">{{cite web | author= Haylee Barber | date= July 11, 2014 | publisher= USA Today | url= http://college.usatoday.com/2014/07/11/10-ways-to-nail-your-college-interview/ | title= 10 ways to nail your college interview | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...1. Dress to impress ... 2. Be prepared ...3. Ask specific questions that cannot be answered from the school’s website ... ... ... 4. Be ready to “tell me a little about yourself”... 5. Don’t ramble... 6. Don’t let your parents do the talking... 7. Prioritize academics...8. Consider bringing something that represents you ...9. Spend some time thinking about what makes you, you ...10. Go confidently in the direction of your dreams ... }}</ref> although a report in 2009 suggested that hiring a fashion consultant and shopping for expensive clothes before an interview was unnecessary and could backfire.<ref name="twsNYT1">{{cite web | author= JACQUES STEINBERG | date= June 12, 2009 | publisher= The New York Times | url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/12/interview/comment-page-9/?_r=0 | title= Free Fashion Advice for College Interviews, From a $15,000 Consultant | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...showcasing “looks” ... for on-campus interviews.... jeans were “a no-no,” and that appearing “neat” and “not sloppy,” while still showing a flash of “your own style,” was key. ... She also advised against “exposing too much,” whether of one’s ankles, toes or cleavage. }}</ref> There is strong consensus that rehearsing for interviews is important.<ref name="twsWashPost3"/> Former [[Phillips Academy|Andover]] theater instructor and professional interview coach Mark Efinger believes that preparation is vital for a successful interview. Private secondary schools such as [[St. Paul's School (New Hampshire)|St. Paul's]] in New Hampshire have a two week "boot camp" in the summer before senior year to help students prepare which includes simulated practice interviews.<ref name="twsBaltSun1">{{cite web | author= Jon Meoli | date= August 15, 2012 | publisher= Baltimore Sun | url= http://www.baltimoresun.com/explore/baltimorecounty/news/ph-tt-st-paul-bootcamp-0815-20120814-story.html | title= St. Paul's 'boot camp' gives seniors a leg up on college applications | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=... the class to run through some simulated interviews ... present themselves in a college interview... }}</ref> Efinger advises students to write up their major achievements, organize them into themes, and have a three to five minute theme-oriented "success story" ready (but not memorized) before an interview, and suggests that interviewees should try to steer the conversation to show how their skills and experience meet criteria valued by the interviewer. For example, if trying to demonstrate an aptitude for "planning and organization", he or she might show how they plan their schedule using their mobile scheduling app.
Advisers agree that a usual open-ended question to begin the interview will be along the lines of "tell me about yourself", and that a student should be ready with a response.<ref name="twsBuffaloSuntimes">{{cite web | author= Buffalo News | date= February 3, 2015 | publisher= Buffalo Suntimes | url= http://buffalo.suntimes.com/buf-entertainment/7/116/71751/countdown-to-college-how-to-impress-in-the-college-interview | title= Countdown to College: How to impress in the college interview | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=... tiptoe that fine line between bragging about their accomplishments and sharing significant information....It’s a safe bet that you’ll be asked a very general question such as, “Tell me about yourself.” ... }}</ref> Several emphasize the importance of being able to back up adjectives such as "hardworking" and "motivated" with a brief and memorable anecdote to explain further what is meant.<ref name="twsBuffaloSuntimes"/><ref name="twsBostonGlobe4">{{cite web | author= Sanjay Salomon | date= January 30, 2015 | publisher= Boston Globe | url= http://www.boston.com/jobs/news/2015/01/30/can-failure-resume-help-you-succeed/uTBdq9A7LfXXF7vVOlG9oM/story.html | title= Can a Failure Resume Help You Succeed? | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...A “failure resume” is ... a private exercise ... outline what they learned from the experience ... Mark Efinger is president and founder of Interview Skill Coaching Academy in Great Barrington, where he prepares candidates for the job interview experience. ...“}}</ref> Efinger describes such anecdotes as "arrows" designed to "hit the bull’s-eye" to make a point which sticks in the interviewer's mind; in addition, interview preparation can include a private soul-searching exercise called a "failure resume" to get students to think about their past mistakes in order to help them outline what they learned from their experience.<ref name="twsBostonGlobe4"/> It helps for students to understand what they want and to show how a particular college can help them achieve their long range goals.<ref name="twsLATimes1">{{cite web | author= VICTORIA NAVARRO | date= December 17, 2015 | publisher= Los Angeles Times | url= http://highschool.latimes.com/granada-hills-charter-high-school/tips-on-how-to-excel-in-a-college-interview/ | title= Tips on how to excel in a college interview | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=... people should be cautious of is trying too hard....the best you can do is understand what you want and how that college can help you achieve your goals. ... }}</ref><ref name="twsUSAToday3">{{cite web | author= Katherine Kendig | date= October 11, 2013 | publisher= USA Today | url= http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/10/11/college-interview-tips/2965129/ | title= Tips for taking the awkward out of college interviews | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...Decide ahead of time what you're going to call your interviewer (formal is probably better to start), and plan some small talk....Know yourself....Know the school.... }}</ref> While interviews can be stressful, one report suggested that the main purpose of the interview was to "show that you are a good person" who is "polite and interesting" with a "sense of humor".<ref name="twsWashPost3">{{cite web | author= Staff writer | date= June 24, 2010 | publisher= Washington Post | url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/22/AR2010062203429.html | title= Don't be afraid to take risks during college interviews | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...Similar practice interviews would be good for students today. ...The point of the interview is to show that you are a good person and that you are polite and interesting and have a sense of humor... }}</ref> Another report suggested the most important thing, when an applicant has strong grades and test scores and activities, is simply not "blowing the interview", although this varies by college.<ref name="twsChicagoTribune3">{{cite web | date= February 5, 2015 | publisher= Chicago Tribune | url= http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/post-tribune/lifestyles/ct-ptb-bradshaw-column-st-0206-20150205-story.html | title= Don't fumble on an otherwise strong college admission run | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...The biggest risk of not getting into Harvard is blowing your interview. ... Yale is big on interviews... }}</ref>
